articles.title: Federal NOAA cuts hit Seattle offices
articles.author: Isabella Breda
articles.summary: Some 880 NOAA employees were fired across the U.S. on Thursday. Some 12,000 people are employed by NOAA, including scientists at the Alaska and Northwest Fisheries Science Centers, the Emergency Response Division and the National Weather Service in Seattle. Sen. Maria Cantwell, D-Wash., is among the critics of the cuts.

articles.title: World War II mine discovered on Gold Coast beach in 1966
articles.summary: A German mine from World War II washed ashore at Surfers Paradise on March 15, 1966. It posed a significant threat to the popular Australian beach. It was removed by the Australian authorities.   .   "The mine is no longer a hazard for surfers.

articles.title: ODU analysis: A Category 3 hurricane could cause $15.6B in damage to Hampton Roads
articles.author: Sean C. Davis
articles.summary: Hurricane Florence could have caused up to $15.6 billion in damage to the Hampton Roads area if it made a direct hit on the region. Most of the damage to buildings would occur to residential homes and apartments. The paper stresses the importance of expanding flood insurance coverage.

articles.title: Donald Trump's surprise admission about Australian alliance, wild and hot weather forecast, China 'not sorry' over live drills
articles.author: Tom Flanagan
articles.summary: Donald Trump didn't know what AUKUS is. It's a military alliance between the US, UK and Australia. Australia has committed more than $300 billion to the alliance. The Bureau of Meteorology has released its long-range autumn forecast, with higher than average temperatures expected across the country. Cairns is experiencing king tides over the next few days.

articles.title: Georgia lawmakers trying to approve $200 million for Hurricane Helene relief.
articles.summary: The State Senate advances budget amendments as farmers struggle with Helene damage, which has damaged the state's water supply.       in the state budget amendments, the state Senate advances the amendments.  In the bill, the amendments are:

articles.title: The spectacular spring migration of birds
articles.summary: Daisy Yuhas is a science writer who writes for Scientific American and other publications. She has written a book called "KIDS' FIELD GUIDE TO BIRDS: 80+ Species Profiles, How to Get Started, Activities and Fun Facts". It was the winner of the 2024 National Outdoor Book Award for children.

articles.title: Increasing confidence cyclone won't make landfall
articles.author: Savannah Meacham
articles.summary: A tropical cyclone is less likely to make landfall on the Queensland coast. It briefly intensified to a category four storm but is no longer a threat to the coast.    - Agnes van der Wijngaarden. For confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90 or visit a local Samaritans branch or click here.

articles.title: Douglas: Outlook is mild, with more rain than snow
articles.author: Paul Douglas
articles.summary: There is emerging research linking rapid warming of the Arctic with changes in the jet stream. Weaker winds aloft may set the stage for brief and intense polar vortex outbreaks. La Niña cooling phase of the Pacific this winter often results in colder weather for Minnesota. After a chilly Saturday around 30 degrees, 40s return from next week into mid-March.

articles.title: Climate Council: If The World Follows Trump's Climate Lead, Australia will Have More Beach Weather
articles.author: Eric Worrall
articles.summary: The Climate Council is warning that Australia's biggest cities could face dangerously hot temperatures unless action is taken to slow down climate change. US President Donald Trump promised to withdraw from the Paris accord and exploit its large oil and gas reserves. Australia will suffer from extreme heat for more than half of every year if the world does not cut back on burning fossil fuels.

articles.title: A central luxury oasis
articles.summary: Birdsong 279 Piper Street, Bathurst is a beautiful Pise cottage built in the 1830s. The house was lovingly renovated in 2017. It is a combined living, kitchen, and lounge area with solid wood beam archways and sixteen feet ceilings. The walls are one foot deep earth and straw with limewash render.

articles.title: How can we improve Tampa Bay's water quality? We're about to find out.
articles.author: Tampa Bay Times
articles.summary: Tampa Bay's fate is tied to its water supply. Red tide outbreaks and pollution made worse by hurricanes are threats to the water supply in the Tampa Bay region. The Spotlight series shines a light on the big issues that impact all of us as a region.

articles.title: Warming slows in Gulf of Maine but temperatures remain high
articles.author: Patrick Whittle
articles.summary: The Gulf of Maine is warming faster than most of the world's oceans. Last year was the gulf's 12th warmest year on record, but it was down from the fifth warmest a year earlier. The gulf is home to some of the country's most valuable seafood species and critical to the American lobster industry.

articles.title: Climate Risk Index 2025 and Pakistan
articles.author: Raza Hussain Qazi
articles.summary: The latest Climate Risk Index (CRI) 2025 by Germanwatch, released in February 2025, highlights the escalating impacts of climate change and the urgent need for enhanced resilience measures. The report assesses data spanning from 1993 to 2022 based on annual average values over 30 years. Dominica, China and Honduras emerge as the countries most affected by extreme weather. Pakistan, Belize and Italy stand out for their high relative economic losses.

articles.title: From the Ground Up: Flying south for unexpected dose of spring
articles.author: I'd forgotten
articles.summary: Warmth is more important than temperature at this time of the year, as I forgot about it.   Â. Â      yestar is the most important thing in the winter, after the temperature. Yestar's

articles.title: From the Ground Up: Flying south for unexpected dose of spring
articles.author: Pam Baxter
articles.summary: I'd forgotten that warmth is more than a temperature, especially at this time of year. Already subscribed to this magazine? Sign up here.      .   "I'd like to know what's going on in your life?"

articles.title: From the Ground Up: Flying south for unexpected dose of spring
articles.author: Pam Baxter
articles.summary: From the Ground Up is flying south for an unexpected dose of spring. He'd forgotten that warmth is more than a temperature, especially at this time of the year. He's flying south to see his family.       for the first time.

articles.title: Flagler Beach's Days Are Numbered. That's No Reason for Palm Coast to Assist Its Suicide.
articles.author: Ed P
articles.summary: The sea is rising due to climate change. Flagler County will pay for beach renourishment and maintenance from here on. Residents of the barrier island will pay an extra $160 a year as part of a special taxing district. The plan needs an additional $12 million a year.

articles.title: How to make Dar resilient amid climate change, urbanisation
articles.summary: Dar es Salaam is one of Africa's fastest-growing urban centres. It is susceptible to rising sea levels and extreme weather events. A conference organised by the African Centre for Sustainable Cities Studies was held on Wednesday. Experts, policymakers, and researchers from 16 countries discussed solutions tailored for coastal cities. The conference also discussed the 10-year research project funded by the Belgian government at a cost of Sh16.2 billion.

articles.title: Columbia University's Public Health School Unveils New Climate and Health
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: The Center for Achieving Resilience in Climate and Health at Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health has been established. It aims to address the health impacts of climate change and advance the capacity of communities and populations to adapt to it. The European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service confirmed that 2024 marked the first year global temperatures exceeded 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: If we've missed the 1.5-degree climate target, what's next?
articles.summary: Earth has crossed the critical 1.5 C warming threshold, according to two major global studies. Scientists say there is still hope for keeping warming below the next target of 2 C, but it's not likely to happen anytime soon, they say. It's more likely to be less than 2 C.

articles.title: Study finds early life on Earth got a boost from ... Glaciers and uranium?
articles.author: N'dea Yancey-Bragg
articles.summary: Giant glaciers covered Earth's surface 700 million years ago. They created rivers that scraped parts of the Earth's crust, releasing minerals and setting off chemical chain reactions that reshaped the planet. Earth was so cold at the time that the oceans were frozen all the way to the equator and life only existed in the oceans and on continental shelves.

articles.title: New England ocean warming slows but temperatures remain high
articles.summary: Last year was the Gulf of Maine's 12th warmest year on record, but it was down from the previous year. The gulf's average annual sea surface temperatures have been warming at a rate of 0.84 degrees Fahrenheit per decade from 1982 to 2024. This is nearly triple the rate of the world's oceans.

articles.title: In a fast-changing world, integrated risk management is vital
articles.summary: The nature of risk is changing for companies. Climate change, geopolitical instability and cybersecurity are the top three emerging risks. Companies need to prepare for the unexpected and create cultures that are built on preparedness and awareness. Technology is set to play an increasing role in prevention and mitigation.

articles.title: Healthcare providers have a critical role to play in climate change preparedness for women's health, but they also need to develop soft skills and support the development of allied community workers, argues Alison Malmqvist, a Vice President and Climate Health lead at Population Services International, an organisation working to improve the quality and affordability of healthcare around the world.
articles.summary: There is a disproportionate impact of climate change on women's health outcomes in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). Community health workers play a vital role in providing care to women in LMICs, especially during climate crises. The World Health Organization and other institutions are looking for ways to upskill health workers. Technology is already adopted worldwide to reduce disparities in access to care and train healthcare providers.

articles.title: Scientists match Earth's ice age cycles with orbital shifts
articles.author: Science X staff
articles.summary: Study tracks the natural cycles of the planet's climate over a million years. It found a predictable pattern over the past million years for the timing of when Earth's climate changes between glacial 'ice ages' and mild warm periods called interglacials. The authors found that we should currently be in the middle of a stable interglacial period and the next ice age would begin many millennia in the future.

articles.title: Slam on climate change was no joke
articles.author: The Acorn Staff
articles.summary: Barry Davis is critical of The Acorn's February 21 editorial regarding fire debris. He is also critical of the cartoon that put all the blame for the fires on politicians and dismissed 'global warming' on the editorial page. Barry wants to know if the Acorn supports the science behind climate change.

articles.title: Study reveals how Earth's orbit controls ice ages
articles.author: Issam AHMED
articles.summary: The Earth's next ice age is expected to begin in about 11,000 years unless human-caused global warming disrupts natural cycles. The research team examined a million-year record of climate change focusing on land-based ice sheets across the Northern Hemisphere and deep ocean temperatures. The last glaciation ended approximately 11,700 years ago.

articles.title: Study reveals how Earth's orbit controls ice ages
articles.author: Issam AHMED
articles.summary: The Earth's next ice age is expected to begin in about 11,000 years unless human-caused global warming disrupts natural cycles, according to a new study published in Science. Earth's orbit around the Sun has historically triggered massive climate changes, the study found.

articles.title: Study reveals how Earth's orbit controls ice ages
articles.author: Issam Ahmed
articles.summary: Scientists have long recognized a connection between Earth's orbit and ice ages, but until recently they struggled to pinpoint which orbital parameters were responsible for starting and ending these glacial cycles. articles.title: Study reveals how Earth's orbit controls ice ages
articles.author: Issam Ahmed
articles.summary: Scientists have long recognized a connection between Earth's orbit and ice ages, but until recently they couldn't pinpoint which orbital parameters were responsible for starting and ending these glacial cycles. Walter Diaz is a scientist at the University of California, Santa Barbara and author of the book "The Earth and Its Oceans".

articles.title: The parts of our region that will be hardest hit by climate inaction
articles.author: Newsroom
articles.summary: Tamworth, Moree, and Gunnedah can expect to see an increase in the number of hot days under unchecked climate change, according to a new modelling.      .   "Climate change" is a human-caused phenomenon.

articles.title: Cyclone Garance Threatens Reunion: Macron Urges Vigilance
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Cyclone Garance is advancing on Reunion with winds of up to 155 kph. Residents are urged to stay indoors, secure certain areas of their homes and prepare for possible power and water outages. The government has assured the public of its support and mobilized resources.

articles.title: Scientists Correlate Earth's Ice Age Cycles with Orbital Modifications
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: The Earth has cycled through alternating periods of intense cold, known as ice ages, and warmer interglacial phases. The last major glaciation period, which culminated around 11,700 years ago, ushered in a warmer, stable Interglacial phase known as the Holocene. The research proposes that the natural inclination towards another ice age, projected to occur in approximately 10,000 years, may be due to anthropogenic influences on climate dynamics.

articles.title: Australia's heat spell ongoing; spring and summer warmest on record
articles.author: Tom Saunders
articles.summary: This summer has been one of the hottest on record. It was the sixth and seventh warmest on record for Hobart and Perth, but the rest of the capitals were ranked between 10th and 16th warmest. The trend of abnormal heat and variable rainfall is likely to persist. The BOM's latest three-month outlook indicates a mean temperature more than 1.5C above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: Trump's Climate Policy Reversal: Scientific Concerns Unveiled
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Scientists argue that evidence of global warming's adverse effects is undeniable. The past decade has strengthened the scientific basis for previous climate assessments. There is expanding evidence that links climate change with national security risks, economic downturns, and healthcare crises. This contrasts sharply with the political effort to dilute protective environmental regulations.

articles.title: SA bushfire season to last until late autumn amid record low rainfall
articles.author: Elsie Adamo
articles.summary: The bushfire season in South Australia is likely to be extended to late autumn due to drought conditions. January rainfall across most of the state was in the lowest 10 per cent on record after a year of record-dry conditions across many regions. For farmers, an extended fire season will mean more work and more worry.

articles.title: Scientists scorn EPA push to say climate change isn't a danger, say just look around at the world
articles.summary: Trump's administration wants to reverse a cornerstone finding that climate change endangers human health and welfare. 11 scientists say new research and ever more frequent extreme weather further prove the harm climate change is doing to people and the planet. They cite peer-reviewed studies and challenge the Trump administration to justify its own effort with science.

articles.title: Trump's war on climate science is pushing us into a dystopian future
articles.author: Corey J. A. Bradshaw
articles.summary: Donald Trump has withdrawn support for any research that mentions climate change. He has also launched a purge on government websites hosting climate data. Last year was the warmest on record. The world has already surpassed the 1.5°C threshold increase relative to pre-industrial temperatures. The US is the second-highest greenhouse gas emitter in the world, behind China.

articles.title: Study Reveals How Earth's Orbit Triggers Ice Ages, And There's One in The Next 11,000 Years
articles.author: Michelle Starr
articles.summary: New research shows the precise relationship between past ice ages and each wobble, tilt, and angle of the planet's path. Earth's orbit around the Sun isn't perfectly symmetrical, with the Sun off-center in the oval shape. The position of the oval in space shifts a little with each orbit. The tilt of Earth's rotational axis, a property known as obliquity, changes as it orbits the Sun. This is responsible for the onset of an ice age. For the last 800,000 years, ice ages have ended every 100,000. years.

articles.title: Next ice age would hit Earth in 11,000 years if it weren't for climate change, scientists say
articles.author: Sascha Pare
articles.summary: Next ice age will begin within the next 10,000 years due to human-driven global warming. Earth's position and angle relative to the sun affect ice sheet formation. Earth is currently in an interglacial period, with the last glacial period having peaked around 20,00 years ago.

articles.title: Climate change threatens homes in Waicoka
articles.summary: Waicoka in Bau, Tailevu, is threatened by rising sea levels and extreme weather. Their community hall is unsafe due to weakened beams and structural damage. The community continues to strengthen the seawall by heightening it, although water keeps encroaching.

articles.title: Nigeria loses 40 meters of land annually to coastal erosionMinister
articles.author: Punch
articles.summary: Southern Nigeria is losing 30 to 40 meters of land to coastal erosion every year. The Minister of Innovation, Science, and Technology, U.S., calls for urgent intervention to stop the erosion.      Â  ...  .

articles.title: Climate change drives rising numbers of refugees in Ntoroko district
articles.summary: As extreme weather events intensify, more people are forced to flee their homes. Today, we focus on climate refugees in Ntoroko District, western Uganda, because of the rising number of refugees due to climate change, which is a growing driver of global migration and displacement.

articles.title: Mahama prioritises sea defence projects to protect coastal communities
articles.summary: President John Dramani Mahama has announced that his administration will prioritise the construction of sea defence projects to safeguard coastal communities threatened by floods and rising sea levels. Two-thirds of Ghana's coastline is threatened by tidal wave erosion, impacting nearly 30 per cent of the population. Urban flooding has become a recurring disaster in many parts of the country.

articles.title: Delhi records warmest February night in 74 years at 19.5°C
articles.author: Statesman News Service
articles.summary: Delhi experienced its warmest February night in 74 years on Thursday. The minimum temperature reached 19.5°C. The highest recorded minimum temperature in February was 16°C on February 25, 2015. The air quality remained poor, with the Air Quality Index (AQI) recorded at 215.

articles.title: What's ‘fool's spring' and could Portland see more winter weather?
articles.author: Josh Cozart
articles.summary: February's expected to end on a high note with afternoon temperatures warming nearly 10-15 degrees warmer than average. Near record-breaking highs are possible for some along the Willamette Valley on Thursday and Friday as temperatures climb into the mid to upper-60s. March 2025 outlook puts much of the Pacific Northwest under a cooler and wetter weather pattern. This would be the'second winter' portion of seasonal timeline.

articles.title: Inside the fight to save the last Victorian Highlands forest fairies
articles.author: Bianca Hall
articles.summary: It takes at least 120 years for mountain ash and alpine ash to develop hollows critical for gliders and Leadbeater's possums to survive. The Victorian government's logging ban took effect at the beginning of January, but old-growth trees are still being felled for commercial logging on private land. The Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action (DEECA) plans to construct up to 6000 kilometres of fire-break tracks through state forests and national parks by 2030. Environmental groups have repeatedly written to DEECA about the strategic fuel-break program.

articles.title: Over 500,000 Afghans displaced in 2024: IOM
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: More than half a million people in Afghanistan were displaced due to climate disasters in 2024. 39 people were killed this week due to floods, hail and storms in southwestern Afghanistan. Afghanistan is among the poorest countries in the world after decades of war and is ranked the sixth most vulnerable to climate change.

articles.title: New England ocean warming slows but temperatures remain high
articles.author: PATRICK WHITTLE
articles.summary: The Gulf of Maine is warming faster than most of the world's oceans. Last year was the 12th warmest year on record, but it was down from the fifth warmest a year earlier. The gulf is home to some of the country's most valuable seafood species and is critical to the American lobster industry.

articles.title: New England ocean warming slows but temperatures remain high
articles.author: PATRICK WHITTLE
articles.summary: Waters off New England had another warm year, but didn't heat up as fast as earlier this decade. Gulf of Maine emerged as a test case for climate change about a decade ago. The gulf is home to some of the country's most valuable seafood species and critical to the American lobster industry.

articles.title: How Greenland's cherished sled dog tradition is threatened by climate change
articles.author: Ashley Brown
articles.summary: Stella Davidsen Olsen was 12 years old when her father asked her and her twin sister if they would like to take care of the dogs. Now, 14 years later, she's raising a family of her own. The number of sled dogs in Greenland has been cut in half over the last 20 years from 25,000 to 13,000 animals. Greenlanders have relied on sled dogs for transportation and hunting.

articles.title: How Greenland's cherished sled dog tradition is threatened by climate change
articles.summary: Climate change has impacted virtually every part of life in Greenland. The tradition of dog sledding illustrates just one aspect of what's at risk for the island as the earth warms. On air now playing KPBX 91.1, KPBZ 90.3 PRX Remix and KSFC 91.9.

articles.title: Spring in Massachusetts has warmed by approximately 2.5 degrees over the past 55 years
articles.author: Bhaamati Borkhetaria
articles.summary: Suffolk County, which includes Boston, has seen the highest temperature rise, with an increase of 2.9 degrees, followed closely by Nantucket County at 2.8 degrees. Franklin County, Norfolk County, Worcester County, and Middlesex County all warmed by 2.6 degrees. Last year was the warmest year on record and breached the 1.5 degrees Celsius threshold for the first time.

articles.title: Rebuilding Resilience: Life After Kenya's 2024 Floods
articles.author: archyde
articles.summary: Kenya's March-to-May rainy season of 2024 brought significant flooding to Nairobi's Mathare informal settlement. Over 7,000 people were displaced in Mathare, the second-largest slum in the Kenyan capital. The number of displaced people rose from 18.4 million in May 2024 to over 20 million by September 2024 due to climate change and El Niño weather phenomenon.

articles.title: Southern Nigeria Loses 40 Meters Land Annually To Coastal ErosionMinister
articles.author: New Telegraph
articles.summary: Southern Nigeria loses 30 to 40 meters of land to coastal erosion every year. Chief Uche Geoffrey Nnaji is the Minister of Innovation, Science, and Technology. He made the revelation in a statement issued by the Director of Media and Corporate Communications at the National Space Research and Development Agency.

articles.title: The meltdown at the top of the world
articles.author: Taipei Times
articles.summary: The UN has declared this year to be the wake-up call to the world. Development institutions must take urgent action to avoid the disastrous effects of accelerating glacial melt, which would devastate local economies and fuel instability worldwide. Masatsugu Asakawa is from Japan.

articles.title: Farmers Sue USDA Over Removal of Climate Data from Website
articles.author: Tim Bruno
articles.summary: Farmers and environmental advocacy groups have filed a lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Agriculture. The agency removed climate change-related tools, data sets, and services from its website. The lawsuit claims the removal of vital resources was unlawful and harmful to farmers.

articles.title: Disastrous Atlantic current shutdown is unlikely this century, new study says
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is a key factor in global weather systems. Scientists at the UK's Met Office and the University of Exeter used simulations from 34 different computer models of extreme climate change scenarios to see if the AMOC would collapse this century. No simulation showed a total shutdown before 2100. The AMOC is now around 17 Sverdrups, down two from about 2004.

articles.title: Living in a hot climate? You could be ageing faster than you think
articles.author: Craig Saueurs
articles.summary: Scientists from the University of Southern California examined data from more than 3,600 people aged 56 and older across the United States. They found that those living in areas with frequent days above 32°C had an accelerated biological age, sometimes by more than a year. The study highlights the urgent need to protect vulnerable populations from heat-related health risks.

articles.title: One Of Earth's Largest Known Supereruptions Dramatically Altered The Climate 79,500 Years Ago
articles.author: Rachael Funnell
articles.summary: The Los Chocoyos supereruption of Guatemala's Atitlán volcanic system occurred around 79,500 years ago. It was followed by catastrophic changes to global climate systems, but this didn't continue at a centennial- or millennial-scale. The planet bounced back to its pre-eruption conditions within a matter of decades.

articles.title: The Urban Heat Island Effect: Why Cities Stay Warmer Than Surrounding Areas
articles.author: Jonathan Novack
articles.summary: Cities like Houston and other urban centers experience higher temperatures than their surrounding rural areas due to the Urban Heat Island effect. Concrete and asphalt surfaces absorb solar radiation during the day and release it slowly overnight. This can lead to temperature differences of 5 to 10 degrees F between urban and rural locations.

articles.title: Weak rocks and melting ice sheet explain rapid ground uplift in Southeast Greenland
articles.author: Gunn Kristin Tjoflot
articles.summary: Satellite data shows that the coastline of Greenland's southeastern part is rising more rapidly than the rest of the island. This is due to the melting of the ice sheet and a hot plume of rock rising from the deep interior of the Earth beneath Iceland. This plume weakened the rocks beneath southeast Greenland and caused the ground to rise more than 12 mm per year.

articles.title: Spring 2025 Hummingbird Sightings and Migration: The Journey North Begins
articles.author: Jeremy Newman
articles.summary: As spring approaches, hummingbird migration is well underway. Many hummingbirds spend the winter in Central America or Mexico before embarking on their long journey north to their breeding grounds. The first sightings occur in the southern United States, followed by later arrivals further north as spring progresses. The last hummingbirds will cross the southern U.S. border in late October.

articles.title: How Chinese PLA's latest forays off Australia cap years of maritime tensions
articles.author: South China Morning Post
articles.summary: Australia's growing presence in South China Sea and Taiwan Strait seen to underscore commitment to Western aims to curb China's influence. Australia's presence in the region is seen as a sign of its commitment to the Western aims.      Â

articles.title: Intense heat changes our biology and can make us age significantly faster: study
articles.author: Rongbin Xu
articles.summary: The more days of intense heat a participant endured, the faster they aged. Longer periods of extreme heat accelerated aging in older people by more than two years. As the climate heats up, humans will be exposed to more and more heat and our bodies will respond to these stresses by aging faster.

articles.title: WATCH: Satellite images reveal how Lake Erie has frozen over
articles.author: Matt Taylor
articles.summary: It's been a harsh winter for those living in the north of the US and eastern Canada. Numerous surges of Arctic air have brought plunging temperatures and frequent snowfall. The impact can be seen over the snow-covered landscape and the frozen surface of the Great Lakes. Lake Erie has been experiencing some of its greatest level of ice coverage in ten years.

articles.title: The sea is swallowing an African island
articles.author: The Economist
articles.summary: Melvin Kargbo lives on Nyangai, a small island off the coast of Sierra Leone. The island has shrunk from 700 metres in length a decade ago to about 90 metres now. Most of its mango and coconut trees have been felled by the waves.

articles.title: Pakistan scales up climate resilience with DAP for Badin, Dera Ghazi Khan
articles.author: Urdu Point
articles.summary: A national workshop was held to consult on the District Adaptation Plans for Badin, Sindh, and Dera Ghazi. The DAPs aim to provide localized solutions by conducting comprehensive climate risk assessments, aligning with district development priorities, and implementing nature-based solutions.

articles.title: Europe's hottest city with temperatures reaching 40C is just 3 hours from UK
articles.author: Rom Preston-Ellis
articles.summary: Valletta, the capital of Malta, is Europe's warmest city, with an average temperature of 19.3C and a daytime average of 23C. The Sirocco winds from Africa bring warm, dry weather to North Africa and Southern Europe, sometimes reaching hurricane speeds. Malta is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, home to a wealth of historical buildings, churches, museums and palaces.

articles.title: Over 500,000 Afghans displaced due to climate disasters in 2024: IOM
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: More than half a million people in Afghanistan were displaced due to climate disasters in 2024. Afghanistan is among the poorest countries in the world after decades of war and is ranked the sixth most vulnerable to climate change. 39 people were killed this week due to floods, hail and storms in southwestern Afghanistan, mainly in Farah.

articles.title: Hydrangea cultivars to suit Dunedin's climate
articles.summary: The birds at the aviary in Ōtepoti are in the process of moulting. Gouldian finches are the only ones that are not in the moult stage at the moment, except for the Gouldian ferns, which are munching.

articles.title: Florida moves to rename Gulf of Mexico in official records
articles.summary: The US state's agriculture commissioner Wilton Simpson is the latest to act on the Trump administration's push to implement the name change. The name of the Gulf of Mexico will be changed to the North American continent.      Â  .

articles.title: Climate Change Evidence in France: Debunking Myths and Embracing Reality
articles.author: Nick Inman
articles.summary: Sceptics of global warming say it's a myth. The evidence for it is not conclusive but contestable. The Mediterranean is warming up and storms of this kind are likely to be more violent. In south-west France, there have been mild winters interspersed with exceptionally hot, dry summers for the past 20 years.

articles.title: Death toll from Afghanistan's rain, hail rises to 39, say officials
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: The death toll from recent heavy rain and hail in three Afghan provinces has risen by 10 to 39. Flash floods in the western border province of Farah killed 21 people, while three more were killed when a hail storm caused their house to collapse. Six people were killed in Helmand province, including a child struck by lightning, and nine in Kandahar province.

articles.title: €188k payout in Cooley Peninsula flood scheme
articles.author: Agriland Media
articles.summary: The first batch of payments will be made to farmers affected by flooding on the Cooley Peninsula this week. There have been 51 successful herds in Cooley, with a combined allocation of €188,000. Deputy McGreehan will continue to work with the Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine to put a relief scheme in place for farmers impacted by flooding.

articles.title: Climate-related extreme weather surged 400% over last 50 years: WHO
articles.author: Arlnie Colleene Talain Singca
articles.summary: There has been a 400 percent increase in extreme weather events due to climate change in the last 50 years, according to the WHO Regional Office for Europe. The UN agency also pointed to the impact of climate change on various health issues, including infectious diseases, respiratory and non-communicable diseases, mental health, and injuries such as drownings.

articles.title: Charlotte County Imposes Comprehensive Burn Ban Amid Worsening Drought
articles.author: Source
articles.summary: Charlotte County officials have placed a ban on outdoor fires due to drought conditions. Barbecues, yard waste burning, and land clearing pile burns are prohibited under the new restrictions. The ban does not apply to fireworks and sparklers, which may still be used for celebration.

articles.title: Heat waves speed up aging in older adults
articles.author: Studyfinds Staff
articles.summary: Older adults living in areas with more frequent hot days show signs of accelerated biological aging, as measured through specialized 'epigenetic clocks' that track molecular changes throughout the body. The study examined data from 3,686 adults aged 56 and older across the United States. Every census tract experienced at least some 'caution+' level heat days.

articles.title: Could climate change speed up aging? - WNKY News 40 Television
articles.author: Riley Guertin
articles.summary: the study by the University of Southern California. People living in areas with high temperatures had 14 months of additional biological aging compared to people in cooler areas, according to the study.    You can read about the study online by clicking right here. It's a potential impact of climate change.

articles.title: Klaus Schwab: 'Climate change, if we do not tackle it, could be the next big—let's say—virus, with much more damaging and long-term consequences compared to Covid-19.' (Video) #WEF #WorldEconomicForum

articles.title: Why India is experiencing heatwaves sooner than expected this year
articles.summary: The recent temperatures in Panaji, Goa were at least five times more likely due to human-caused climate change than in Mumbai. Dr. Akshay Deoras from the University of Reading stressed that anthropogenic climate change is escalating both meteorological and hydrological extremes worldwide.

articles.title: Living in extreme heat speeds up ageing: Study
articles.summary: A new study done by researchers from the USC Leonard Davis School of Gerontology has revealed that increased temperatures can accelerate ageing in humans. The research was conducted on 3,600 participants who were 56 years or older in the US. The correlation between a greater number of extreme heat days and an increase in biological age persisted even after controlling for socioeconomic and other demographic differences.

articles.title: Sylvan Heights Bird Park to host Birds, Brews & BBQ
articles.author: Gigi  Barnett
articles.summary: Kat Lewandowski and Aurora from Sylvan Heights Bird Park visited WITN's studio this morning to talk about their upcoming Birds, Brews & BBQ event on March 15th from 5-8 p.m. There will be a BBQ cook-off competition, adults 21+ can enjoy beverage tastings from local brewers and distillers, and there will be plenty of family-friendly activities.

articles.title: Adirondack Climate Conference slated for March 6 at The Wild Center -
articles.author: Community News Reports
articles.summary: The Wild Center and Paul Smith's College will host the Adirondack Climate Conference on March 6th from 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m., bringing together community members, regional leaders, problem-solvers, and students to address climate challenges and possible opportunities in northern New York. Keynote talks will be live-streamed at wildcenter.org/live for those unable to attend in person. Tickets are $45 for adults and $15 for students.

articles.title: Hurricane season is 3 months away. Will it be as active as last year?
articles.author: Ben Noll
articles.summary: The Atlantic hurricane season is less than three months away. Forecasters are making early efforts to understand how this year's hurricane season may differ from the last one. The number of hurricanes can't be predicted this far out, but forecasters can look to planetary climate patterns for clues.

articles.title: Feral chickens a threat to farms, says top farmer

articles.title: Australia's First National Ecosystem Accounts
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Dept of Climate Change, Energy, Environment & Water has developed the first National Ecosystem Accounts. The accounts focus on the size, health and value of Australia's environment. In 2020-21, 5 ecosystem services provided at least $85 billion to support our economy and wellbeing.

articles.title: Autumn Alert: Fire, Flood, Cyclone Risks Persist
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Seasonal Bushfire Outlook for Autumn 2025 has been released by the National Council for Fire and Emergency Services and the Bureau of Meteorology. There is a heightened and increased risk of fire in South Australia, Western Australia, the Nullabor, Mallee, Esperance Plains, Mardabilla regions, south-eastern part of Southwest Land Division, Lesueur Sandplains, and northern Swan Coastal Plain Bioregions in early autumn. The outlook indicates that above average autumn rainfall is likely for the far north of Australia, including the northern Kimberley, the northern half of the Northern Territory and far northern Queensland. The Bureau is tracking the progress of Cyclone Alfred which is

articles.title: Cameron Highlands hits record heat in 2024
articles.summary: 2024 was the hottest year on record for Cameron Highlands, with the average daily temperature being 18.91 deg C. The highest temperature recorded there was 27.9°C on May 19, 1998. 689 landslides were recorded in Cameron Highlands from 1961 until now. Minerals and Geoscience Department has produced a Slope Hazard Map and National Slope Risk Map which identify 45 critical and high-risk slopes there.

articles.title: Grill, Baby, Grill: Aussies Set To Swelter If Leaders Follow Trump's Climate Chaos
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Climate Council's Heat Map tool shows Australia's biggest cities could experience dangerous hotter temperatures in the coming decades without accelerated climate action. The worst heat will hit communities least able to cope with it, including the lowest income electorates and those with the highest proportion of Aussies vulnerable to heat.

articles.title: Scientists' stunning observation of hybrid 'grolar' bear sparks concern: 'Ill-suited to adapt'
articles.author: Chelsea Cook
articles.summary: Grolar bears are hybrid offspring of polar and grizzly bears. They were first spotted in 2006 in the western Arctic. They are poorly suited to both marine and land environments. They cannot fill the ecological roles of their respective species. Conservationists emphasize that protecting polar bear habitats and curbing climate change are urgent priorities for the Arctic.

articles.title: Heavy rain alert for TN's Delta districts, Collectors asked to take precautions
articles.author: The Hans India
articles.summary: There is a heavy rain warning for Delta districts from February 27 to March 1. Some parts of southern Tamil Nadu have already received heavy rain. The alert follows the devastation caused by Cyclone Fengal, which impacted Tamil Nadu and Puducherry between November 29 and December 1. Tamil Nadu has recorded 14 per cent excess rainfall during the ongoing northeast monsoon season.

articles.title: Labor policy change towards Israel is ‘dramatic, worrying and frightening'
articles.summary: Menzies Research Centre senior fellow Nick Cater discusses the revelation of Foreign Minister Penny Wong snubbing the Israeli representative. Mr Cater describes the change in policy towards Israel as 'dramatic' and 'worrying and frightening' for Australians who have been natural allies with them since the formation of the country.

articles.title: Indigenous insights offer key to tackling global crises

articles.title: Blazing Heat: How Extreme Temperatures Accelerate Biological Ageing
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: A genetic study by the University of Southern California shows that extreme heat exposure may speed up biological ageing in older adults. This research, published in Science Advances, links consistent high temperatures with negative health outcomes. The study advocates for specific health interventions and climate policies to counteract the ageing effects of extreme heat.

articles.title: The hottest year in Greece in the last 30 years
articles.author: Denis Dzhambazov
articles.summary: The past year 2024 was the hottest in Greece in the last 30 years, breaking the record set in 2023. The average maximum temperature in all regions of Greece was higher than the average value of the indicator for the period 1991 – 2020. In 85 out of 92 days of the summer of 2024, temperatures with very high positive deviations were recorded in Greece. June 2024 was hottest in recent decades with prolonged periods of high temperatures.

articles.title: Aussies brace for cyclones, fire and rain in ‘warmer than usual' autumn
articles.summary: Aussies brace for cyclones, fire and rain in 'warmer than usual' autumn due to warmer than usual weather.    in Australia this autumn is expected to be warm and dry, but wetter than usual.  in other countries.

articles.title: Climate change threatening very foundation of Nigeria's food system ' FG

articles.title: Glaciers' Current Size Beyond Saving, Say Experts
articles.author: Mirage News

articles.title: Green Shorelines: Innovative solutions for coastal protection and biodiversity conservation in Ghana
articles.summary: Ghana has a 500 km coastline along the Gulf of Guinea. The Volta River Delta and parts of the Western Region have been experiencing significant coastal erosion and habitat loss due to climate change. Green shorelines are nature-based solutions that harness the power of ecosystems such as mangroves, seagrasses, and coastal wetlands. They protect shorelines from erosion and flooding, enhance ecosystem resilience, support local economies, and foster environmental sustainability.

articles.title: Delhi Weather: Record February Heat Signals How Next 3-4 Months Will Be
articles.author: Satyaki Baidya
articles.summary: Delhi hit a record-breaking temperature of 34.1°C on February 26. The minimum temperature in Delhi was 15.4°C, 2.9°C above normal. Humidity levels ranged from 59 to 86% throughout the day. Unseasonably high temperatures in February are an indicator of global warming and climate change.

articles.title: Over 500,000 Afghans displaced due to climate disasters in 2024
articles.author: Kabul
articles.summary: Afghanistan is ranked the sixth most vulnerable to climate change. 80 percent of the population depends on farming to survive. Almost all villages have limited access to emergency services and 96 percent lack resources for crucial measures like early warning systems and search and rescue, according to the IOM.

articles.title: Extreme heat can age you as fast as a smoking habit
articles.author: Zoya Teirstein
articles.summary: Extreme heat has killed more than 21,000 Americans since 1999. People living in places where temperatures are above 90 degrees for half the year have experienced up to 14 months more biological aging compared to people living in areas with fewer than 10 days of temperatures over 90 degrees. The impact of chronic exposure to high temperatures is equivalent to the effect of habitual smoking.

articles.title: Experts Advise on Boosting Mangrove Sustainability
articles.author: Mirage News

articles.title: Moderate Weather Expected Across Egypt on Thursday, Cairo 20°C
articles.author: Yara Sameh
articles.summary: The Egyptian Meteorological Authority predicts moderate weather to prevail in Cairo, Lower Egypt, North Coast, and North Upper Egypt during Thursday's daylight hours. The Mediterranean Sea will experience low to moderate waves, ranging between 1 and 1.5 meters in height with northwest surface winds. Extremely cold weather is also expected in Egypt in the early hours and at the end of the nighttime.

articles.title: Computer simulations show collapse of vital Atlantic current that warms Europe unlikely this century
articles.author: Euronews Green
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation or AMOC is now around 17 Sverdrups, down two from about 2004 with a trend of about 0.8 decline per decade. Scientists at the UK's Met Office and the University of Exeter used simulations from 34 different computer models of extreme climate change scenarios to see if the AMOC would collapse this century. No simulation showed a total shutdown before 2100. An AMOC shutdown brings its own climate impacts.

articles.title: Europe deep freeze from Atlantic current collapse unlikely this century, computer simulations show
articles.author: Euronews Green
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation or AMOC is now around 17 Sverdrups, down two from about 2004 with a trend of about 0.8 decline per decade. Scientists at the UK's Met Office and the University of Exeter used simulations from 34 different computer models of extreme climate change scenarios to see if the AMOC would collapse this century. No simulation showed a total shutdown before 2100. An AMOC shutdown brings its own climate impacts.

articles.title: ⚡When Is International Polar Bear Day 2025? All About the Day Dedicated to Protection of Polar Bears
articles.summary: Polar bears rely on sea ice to hunt for seals, their primary food source. Due to rising global temperatures, the ice melts earlier in the season, making it harder for them to find food. This day focuses on addressing both the long- and short-term challenges that polar bears face.

articles.title: 1st Ocean Decade Int'l Coastal Cities Conference held in Qingdao, E China
articles.author: 新华网
articles.summary: The first Ocean Decade International Coastal Cities Conference was held in Qingdao, east China's Shandong Province on Wednesday. The conference themed "Better Ocean, Better City" was held to facilitate knowledge exchange and experience sharing on blue economy, climate change, and science-based solutions for sustainable development of coastal cities.

articles.title: Liberal candidate's climate comment drives donations
articles.author: Dominic Giannini
articles.summary: Mr Constance's view on climate change hasn't changed since the Black Summer bushfires, when he called for it to be taken seriously and for more action to mitigate climate risks. He still believes in taking climate change seriously and taking action to reduce its risks.

articles.title: Protect yourself from extreme heat
articles.author: Sylvester Ojenagbon
articles.summary: Last week, the Nigerian Meteorological Agency predicted a prolonged heatwave across the country. However, the downpour in some parts of the country after that prediction seems to have exacerbated the already frightening situation. Extreme heat is often associated with heatwaves. In Nigeria, it is considered to be temperatures exceeding 38°C. It can have serious consequences for human health.

articles.title: MAKABE AND OBATH: Youth must champion climate action
articles.author: Morris Makabe
articles.summary: African countries are losing nearly 5% of their GDP due to climate change-related disasters. More than 118 million people in Africa will face drought, floods, and extreme heat by 2030. Climate change is a collective global responsibility. Young people are the future leaders of the world. They can leverage innovative ideas to tackle climate change.

articles.title: Alaska Science Forum: Northern soil microbes staying up all winter
articles.summary: Grant Falvo reported high winter emissions of carbon dioxide and methane from Alaska permafrost sites he visited in 2024. Permafrost underlies one-quarter of the globe's land and more than half of Alaska. It's thawed so deeply in places that it doesn't re-freeze in winter, allowing microbes to emit greenhouse gases even if cold air has frozen the ground.

articles.title: Severe Heat Accelerates Aging, Alters Biology: Study
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The more days of intense heat a participant endured, the faster they aged. Longer periods of extreme heat accelerated ageing in older people by more than two years. articles.title: ‘Include the science'

articles.title: Long periods of extreme heat can accelerate biological age, scientists say
articles.author: Yahoo Daily News
articles.summary: Longer periods of extreme heat accelerate biological age in older adults by up to two years, according to new research. More heat days over time correlated with deterioration at the molecular and cellular level in adults, as well as at the cellular level, as the research found.

articles.title: Storm Eowyn: Cumberland council count cost of damage
articles.author: Ian Duncan
articles.summary: Members of the full council are due to meet at the Civic Centre in Carlisle on Tuesday (March 4) from 1pm. Helen Davison will ask about the financial impact of the Storm Eowyn clean-up and how the council's expenditure compares to the broader costs borne by other organisations and local economy.

articles.title: Regional Australia Faces Heat Surge Amid Climate Crisis
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Climate Council's new heat map tool shows that regional electorates will face some of the worst increases in hot days if Australia and other nations fail to follow through on their current climate commitments. The worst heat will hit communities least able to cope with it, including poor electorates, those with greater numbers of older Australians and children under five.

articles.title: CoastSnap project launched to monitor Denbighshire coastline
articles.author: Alex Whilding
articles.summary: Denbighshire Countryside Services, Wales Coastal Monitoring Centre and the Wales Coast Path have introduced the CoastSnap project. The citizen science initiative invites the public to submit images of the coast at designated CoastSnap locations via a QR code. The images will help monitor coastal changes over time, particularly coastal erosion and climate change impacts on the shoreline.

articles.title: CoastSnap project invites public to snap photos of Denbighshire coast
articles.author: Alex Whilding
articles.summary: Denbighshire Countryside Services, in partnership with the Wales Coastal Monitoring Centre and the Wales Coast Path, has introduced the CoastSnap project. This citizen science initiative invites the public to submit images of the coast at designated CoastSnap locations via a QR code. The images will help monitor coastal changes over time, particularly coastal erosion and other climate change impacts on the shoreline.

articles.title: The African Union must include climate reparations on its agenda
articles.author: Karabo Mokgonyana
articles.summary: In 2025, the African Union adopted the theme Justice for Africans and People of African Descent Through Reparations. The environmental degradation and the effects of climate change disproportionately affecting Africa are a legacy of colonial-era resource extraction and industrial activities by Global North countries. The argument for climate reparations is rooted in the principle of 'common but differentiated responsibilities'

articles.title: Somalia faces escalating crisis amid drought, conflict and price hikes
articles.author: Undp Somalia
articles.summary: 4.4 million people in Somalia could face "crisis" levels of food insecurity (IPC Phase 3 or higher) between April and June 2025. The hunger crisis is expected to be most severe among internally displaced persons (IDPs), pastoralists with limited livestock and farming households that have exhausted their food supplies. Somalia has suffered consecutive climate shocks.

articles.title: Somalia Crisis Deepens: Drought, Conflict, Price Hikes
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: 4.4 million people in Somalia could face "crisis" levels of food insecurity between April and June 2025, according to new food security assessments. Climate shocks, drought, erratic rainfall and ongoing conflict are eroding livelihoods. 1.7 million children under five are expected to suffer from acute malnutrition in 2025, including 466,000 with severe acute malnutrition. The 2025 Somalia Humanitarian Needs and Response Plan, which requires $1.42 billion, is only 12.4 per cent funded.

articles.title: Autumn bushfire danger as hot and dry conditions linger
articles.summary: Dry and hot conditions are expected to continue into autumn in southern parts of Australia. The danger is tipped to remain elevated in patches between Perth and Carnarvon in WA and along much of Australia's southern coast to Gippsland in Victoria. Hundreds of thousands of hectares have been scorched since November by fires in Victoria and WA.

articles.title: Autumn bushfire danger as hot and dry conditions linger
articles.author: Adrian Black
articles.summary: There could be an increased risk of fire in Wimmera, the South West, the central and west South Gippsland districts as we head into the autumn months, according to Mr Wiebusch. In recent years there has been less fire than in recent years.

articles.title: Autumn bushfire danger as hot and dry conditions linger

The danger is tipped to remain elevated in patches between Perth and Carnarvon in WA and along much of Australia's southern coast to Gippsland in Victoria. Hundreds of thousands of hectares have been scorched since November by fires in Victoria and WA.

articles.title: Penny Wong accuses Coalition of ‘gunboat diplomacy' in Senate estimates as Chinese warships sail into Great Australian Bight
articles.author: Ben Doherty
articles.summary: Three Chinese warships sailed into the Great Australian Bight. Penny Wong accuses the Coalition of stirring controversy over live-fire drills that the flotilla conducted last week in the Tasman Sea. There was no warning that the Chinese ships were live-firing in the sea on Friday morning. 49 commercial flights were forced to divert around the Chinese vessels. Australia and New Zealand have raised the lack of warning with Chinese officials.

articles.title: Warming Makes Reservoir Winter Resort for Cranes
articles.author: AFP-Jiji
articles.summary: Lac du Der was created in the 1970s to stop flood waters heading down the Seine River toward the Paris region. Global warming has made the French reservoir an attractive winter retreat for cranes. The number of migrating birds has increased tenfold in the past decade. Local farmers complain of the damage to their land.

articles.title: Intense heat changes our biology and can make us age significantly faster: study
articles.summary: As the climate heats up, humans will be exposed to more and more heat. Longer periods of extreme heat accelerated ageing in older people by more than two years. The findings are especially pertinent to Australia, where heatwaves are expected to become more frequent and intense.

articles.title: Determining the Sun's Remaining Life: Scientific Insights into Our Solar Star's Halfway Mark
articles.author: archyde
articles.summary: Dr. Ada Stellara explains to Archyde how the sun's aging process will affect Earth's environment. The sun is 5 billion years old and will get hotter as it ages. The carbon cycle will be affected and plants may struggle to survive. The greenhouse effect will intensify. Earth will become a Venus-like planet. Jupiter may be the only planet remaining after 30 billion years.

articles.title: Newborn babies die amid Gaza cold snap, civil defence agency says

articles.summary: Night-time temperatures in Gaza have dipped below 9 degrees Celsius over the past two weeks. Hundreds of thousands of people have been displaced and are living in tents following more than a year of intense Israeli attacks on Gaza. The average temperature in Gaza is 9 degrees C.

articles.title: Extreme Heat Can Accelerate Aging, New Research Finds
articles.author: The Conversation

articles.title: How the 'scientific consensus' on climate change was invented

articles.title: Dead Wood Harvested to Cut Wildfires, Store Carbon
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Prescribed fires in the Western U.S. are an essential tool for managing forests and reducing wildfire risks, but they come with significant social and environmental consequences. Researchers from Florida Atlantic University simulated the effects of eight forest management treatments to see how they affect wildfire risks. They found that combining physical harvesting with thinning significantly reduced risks like tree mortality and crown fires, while lowering carbon emissions and promoting forest resilience.

articles.title: February 2025 in southeast Texas was marked by climate extremes between record heat and deep freezes

If not for the arctic front in the middle of February, this February would probably have been another record-warm one.

articles.title: Eastern Ontario farms take precautions amid bird flu outbreaks

articles.title: Vital ocean current is unlikely to completely shut down this century
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: Even under extreme warming, the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation will weaken but not collapse, according to climate models. This could still have serious impacts, however, if it were to happen in the future, as climate models predict it would be due to warming.

articles.title: Greenland's Ice Sheet Approaches Dangerous Tipping Point Amid Rapid Melting

articles.title: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) Is Safe from Climate Collapse―for Now
articles.author: Scientific American
articles.summary: The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation won't completely collapse with global warming, but any weakening of it could have grave consequences worldwide. It's unlikely that it will completely collapse, but it won't be completely stable, either. It will be unstable.

articles.title: Olive Ridley turtle population growing ‘steadily': Report
articles.author: The Hindu
articles.summary: Rising sand temperatures are raising questions about Olive Ridleys' long-term viability. A large proportion of Olive Ridley females are females.    - a study found that the number of females is increasing because of the rising sand temperatures. - a report found.

articles.title: Extreme heat may speed up aging in older adults
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: A new study suggests greater exposure to extreme heat may accelerate biological aging in older adults. There are new concerns about how climate change and heat waves could affect long-term health and aging at the molecular level, as well as the physical health of older adults, as a result of climate change.

articles.title: Researchers make recommendations for promoting sustainable development in mangrove forest areas
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Although preventing all the consequences of climate change is impossible, we can adopt policies to mitigate its impact, according to the set of policy recommendations published by the UNFCCC. The recommendations are: "Aims to mitigate climate change's impact by adopting policies to reduce its impact".

articles.title: Climate change increases tree mortality risk in urban boreal forests, study finds

articles.title: Climate Risk Index 2025 and Pakistan
articles.author: The News International
articles.summary: The latest Climate Risk Index (CRI) 2025 by Germanwatch highlights the escalating impacts of climate change and the urgent need for action. Pakistan contributes less than one per cent of global greenhouse gas emissions, but it is vulnerable to climate change, as shown by the 2022 floods.

articles.title: DOGE's Chaos Reaches Antarctica
articles.author: Wired
articles.summary: Daily life at US-run Antarctic stations has already been disrupted. Scientists worry that the long-term impacts could upend research and the continent's delicate geopolitics.      .   in this way, the impact on research and geopolitics could be significant.

articles.title: Adapting to climate change is limited by people's behavior: How social innovation can help
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Adapting to climate change is becoming more and more difficult, according to the UNFCCC. It's also getting harder to predict the effects of climate change on society and the economy. It is getting more difficult to adapt to the changing climate, too.

articles.author: Watauga Democrat
articles.summary: The Earth's next ice age is expected to begin in about 11,000 years unless human-caused global warming disrupts natural cycles, according to the scientists.      .   "The Earth’s Next Ice Age" is due to begin unless human activity disrupts the natural cycles.

articles.author: All Africa
articles.summary: The US decision to withdraw from the Paris Agreement raises questions about the future of global policy to mitigate climate change and the role of the US in it.    iReport.com will explore these questions and explore some of the possibilities that could be explored.

articles.summary: Delhi recorded its warmest February night in 74 years with the temperature reaching 19.5 degrees Celsius on Thursday. The summers are already starting to set in already in Delhi and the city is experiencing warm weather already.    The weather is getting warmer in Delhi.

articles.title: Climate change threatens homes in Waicoka
articles.author: FBC News
articles.summary: Waicoka in Bau, Tailevu, is on the frontlines of climate change. Rising sea levels and extreme weather are the main causes of sea level rise and sea-level rise in Waicoka's area.

articles.title: Scientists scorn EPA push to say climate change isn't a danger, say just look around ...
articles.author: San Francisco Chronicle
articles.summary: Donald Trump's administration is trying to reverse a cornerstone finding that climate change endangers human health and welfare. Scientists say they need to look around because it's obvious how bad global warming is, as they say it's already happened.

articles.title: Seasonal changes got you sick? Don't let your skin get affected too; try these 5 ...
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: The season is changing, transitioning from winter to summer, bringing changes in air quality, sunlight exposure and humidity. Fluctuations in temperature, humidity, and environmental factors can stress your skin, leading to dryness, irritation, and even breakouts. Adapting your skincare routine is important to keep your skin healthy and balanced throughout the year.

articles.title: Earth's Glaciers Are Melting at Accelerated Rate
articles.author: Democracy Now
articles.summary: A new study published in the journal Nature finds glaciers are melting at an accelerating rate. This is causing a rise in sea levels, according to the study.   .   2   3   4   5   6   7

articles.title: How extreme heat from climate change could make us all two years older
articles.author: The Independent
articles.summary: Prolonged exposure to heat can increase biological age by up to 2.48 years, according to a study by the University of California at San Francisco.   Â  .   i   in the study, the study found that the increase in biological age is due to heat.

articles.title: Study reveals how Earth's orbit controls ice ages
articles.author: Walter Diaz
articles.summary: The Earth's next ice age is expected to begin in about 11,000 years unless human-caused global warming disrupts natural cycles, according to a new study published Thursday in Science. The study analyzed how subtle shifts in Earth's orbit around the Sun have historically triggered massive climate changes.

articles.title: 5,00,000 Afghans displaced due to climate disasters in 2024: IOM
articles.author: Agence France-Presse . Kabul
articles.summary: Afghanistan is among the poorest countries in the world after decades of war and is ranked the sixth most vulnerable to climate change. 39 people were killed this week due to floods, hail and storms in southwestern Afghanistan, mainly in Farah. Climate-sensitive livelihoods, like subsistence farming, make up 73% of jobs in Afghanistan.

articles.title: Need for clarity to forge ahead
articles.summary: Glaciers are melting at an alarming rate, threatening 700,000 people who depend on them and 1.6 billion people downstream who rely on Himalayan water sources, according to the UNFCCC report.   .   i   1.2 mins read
